newsitem.title: USA: US money managers more bullish Nov 12 wk -- survey.
newsitem.headline: US money managers more bullish Nov 12 wk -- survey.

text.p: Money managers took slightly more-bullish positions in U.S. debt markets in the past week, according to a survey by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc.
"Over the past week, there were two-way flows that marginally resulted in duration extension," the report said.

In the week ended November 12, the survey's bear/bull index arithmetic reading rose to 4.82 from 4.70 the prior week; the asset-weighted number climbed to 4.69 from 4.65 in the week ended November 5, according to the report.
A number above 5.00 is seen as indicating investors are mostly long on the market.
The cash/assets ratio fell to 6.81 percent from 6.93 percent.
Duration bogey held steady at 4.11 on an arithmetic basis and 4.68 on a weighted basis.
Duration bogey is the level of asset or liability duration sought in the management of a portfolio.
Duration refers to a portfolio's average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.

Twenty-eight percent of the portfolio managers polled said they were planning to be active in the coming week, up from 20 percent the week before. The bear/bull index collected among those intending to be active was 6.14, up from 4.8 the previous week.
The Stone & McCarthy survey is conducted by the research firm weekly. It includes 25 market participants with total assets of about $100 billion, the firm said.
* Table provided by Stone and McCarthy Research Associates.
** Respondents intending to adjust portfolio in coming week.
